title: Shinola’s $550 Dive Watch Breathes New Life Into a Scuba Classic
article_text: All products are independently selected by our editors. If you buy something, we may earn an affiliate commission. Dive watches, much like crustaceans, cephalopods, and other creatures of the deep, come in a myriad of differentspecies and subspecies. These include sleek desk divers (pro-spec underwater watches that are refined enough to wear with a suit);beefy ultra-deep divers(ones whose XXL cases are water-resistant to 500m or more); GMT divers (ones with dual-time-zone functions); and vintage-style Super Compressor divers (identifiable by their dual-crown cases and internal rotating bezels.) Then there’s the skin diver, a genus of tough-yet-affordable sports watches popular in the 1960s and 1970s among scuba hobbyists, weekend spear fishermen, and anyone else who wanted to add a dash of nautical swagger to their wardrobe. While not as prestigious as the dive watches made by stalwarts likeRolexand Blancpain, skin divers’ distinctive looks—which included some very funkyMad Men-era dial designs—made them incredibly popular in their day, and their appeal amongvintage watch collectorsremains strong 60 years later. This month, however, there’s a new addition to the skin diver club that can be yours for the (relatively) reasonable sum of $550: the Shinola Duck 1040. Shinola Shinola Shinola Shinola Like the best vintage-modern divers (another important species to spot in the wild), the Duck 1040 combines a heavy dollop of midcentury design cues with a raft of modern upgrades including a 40mm stainless steel case, a sapphire crystal, and a Swiss quartz movement. With an engraving of its namesake bird on the caseback, a period-correct basketweave textured rubber strap, and a selection of dial and accent colors including canary yellow, pastel blue, and bubblegum pink, the Duck has all the hallmarks of a go-to summer ticker. As you’d expect from a brand that’s synonymous withthe Motor City renaissance, every Duck is assembled “from gears to gaskets”, and tested at Shinola’s Detroit HQ. Shinola Shinola Shinola Shinola “For a watch named Duck, the playful visuals of the golden years of the skin diving era felt like a perfect fit,” says Greg Verras, Design Director at Shinola, who pored over old issues ofSkin Divermagazine for inspiration. With 100m of water resistance, the Duck 1040 is water-resistant enough for a day at the lake or the beach, but like its 1960s predecessors, it’s a more casual proposition than other members of the dive watch family, includingShinola’s 300-metre-rated Monster collection. “Skin diving can be a leisure activity, not a technical, highly controlled endeavor—it’s more about having fun, exploring, and getting sunburned,” Verras says. “In the end, a Duck is essentially the skin diver of the bird community.”

title: Men’s Beach Outfits: 26 Surefire Ways to Dress for the Beach
article_text: It's starting to get warmer out. The sun is shining. Do we really need much more of an excuse than that to round up some of the best men's beach outfits of all time and dole out a few helpful style tips to get you looking your absolute bestsur la plagethis summer? Didn't think so. Whether you're flying off on a weeklong trip to the French Riviera or just driving up the road for a picnic by the ocean, here are 26 men's beach vacation outfits worth pinning to your summer mood board. Steve McQueen, 1968 A great pair of shades and Faye Dunaway by your side doesn't hurt, but what makes this look fromThe Thomas Crown Affairso timeless is the interplay between the long sleeves of McQueen's rumpled creamsicle shirt and the thigh-baring inseam of his shorts. A$AP Rocky, 2022 It's summertime and the livin’ is easy. The sand is soft beneath your feet. The ocean is shimmering before you. If you can't let loose and wild out sartoriallynow, when can you? Follow our guyRocky's lead and lean hard into searing neons, clashing patterns, and metallic kicks. John F. Kennedy Jr., 1980 When you're wearing as little asJohn-Johnis here, every detail counts. Thetiny trunksdo plenty of talking, but it's the righteous tooth necklace (and, frankly, the pack of cigs tucked in his waistband) that sends this to a whole other plane of cool. Shawn Mendes, 2023 Speaking of accessories: Thatreal-deal dive watchyou're so proud of? Let it fulfill its intended purpose. Wearing your timepiece beneath the depths is an especially sick flex if, like Mr. Mendes here, you match the band of yourPatek Philippe Aquanautto your trunks. Jackie Chan, 1984 Breton stripesare never not effortlessly cool—and that goes double anytime you happen to be near a body of water. Mick Jagger, 1987 The beach is meant to be relaxing, sure. That doesn't mean yourclothesalways need to be relaxed too. Jagger's graceful pleated trousers and pressed shirt cut a sharp figure, but they don't feel the least bit out of place as he strides across the dunes. Andre Agassi, 1996 There's plenty to love about (and steal from) this Andre Agassi ensemble. The tucked-inlinen shirt! The pleatedjorts! Thebeeper!!!We're gonna zero in on the Grand Slam winner's choice of footwear as the key to the whole thing, though.Fisherman sandalsare about as hot in fashion circles as they've ever been, and they look as good anchoring casual beach outfits as they do dressed up with a crisp summer suit. Jay-Z, 2020 They're called “vacation shirts” for a reason. Louche, laid-back, camp-collared button-ups have been in again for a minute now, which means there are plenty of options—like Jay-Z's smart plaid Bode shirt here—that run a little subtler and more tasteful than your average thrift-store Hawaiian joint. Jay-Z, 2018 Yup, two Jay-Z looks in a row. Turns out, when you're the greatest rapper of all time and also a billionaire you wind up with a lot of stellar vacation photos. Another side effect of dashing off to tropical locales as often as the Carters do? You master galaxy-brain moves like wearing a suit on the sand. Sure, you can always pull off an airy linen number at a beach wedding. But what Hov is doing here is way,waymore striking—kicking back with a stogie in a fiery red two-piece with no shirt underneath is a hall-of-fame maneuver. If you're gonna pack a suit on your weekend getaway, make sure it's one like this: designed for popping bottles, not the boardroom. Julio Iglesias, 1980 There's something that just feels right about a sports jersey at the beach. Maybe it's an old-school football pullover like Julio's, maybe it's asplashy hoops uniform, maybe it's ablokecore-embracing soccer kit. Doesn't hurt if you actually bring a pigskin to toss around, either. Ethan Hawke, 2022 One of the biggest misconceptions about getting dressed in the warmer months is that layering is no longer an option. But a simple tee or tank under a vibey button-up—as the ever-stylishEthan Hawkeexhibits here, decades after downright perfecting the look inReality Bites—gives you plenty of flexibility and versatility for a long day in the sun. Pierce Brosnan, 1999 The rightsunglassesand a greathaircutmake a world of difference. George Harrison, 1976 Who says you can't hit the beach on a blustery November morning? The thinking person's favorite Beatle understands that no matter the temperature, there are few better places for getting off an epic fit. Bruce Willis, 1986 OK, so Bruce is backstage at the Emmys and nowherenearthe ocean here. But this elegant, all-white-everything kit—with a slouchy, wide silhouette that still feels fresh in 2024—was too beachy and beautiful not to share anyway. Sean Connery, 1962 We're not saying they should replace your nylon board shortsallthe time, of course. In a pinch, though, when you're strolling by the shore and decide you really need to take a plunge? A hardy pair of rolled-upchinosworks—and looks!—mighty fine. Serge Gainsbourg and Jane Birkin, 1972 Even less practical than khakis on the beach: A fullCanadian tuxedo,sansshirt butavecwhat appears to be a pair ofhouse slippers. But when you're Serge Gainsbourg—and you've got Jane Birkin on your arm—it makes all the sense in the world. Justin Bieber, 2021 When it's soupy out, the last thing you want is a tight shirt sticking to your torso like saran wrap. The Biebs, of course, is no stranger to jumbo-sized ensembles, but his billowy agenda especially makes sense seaside. Paul Newman, 1958 Even in the dead of summer, it can get pretty chilly down by the ocean at night. And, as my pal Amelia recently put it, there's nothing like wearing a sweater on the beach for feeling like you've been swept up into a swoony Nicholas Sparks novel. Russell Westbrook, 2023 As far as maximizing vibesandsun protection is concerned, you can't beat a goodbucket hat. Matthew McConaughey, 2006 Not really a hat guy? A well-deployed bandana might not offer the same level of cover from the rays, but it sure does look pretty rad. Shirley MacLaine and Steve Parker, 1955 An open-collar, tunic-style shirt like this one feels relaxed enough for a vacation, but still handsome and put-together enough for a dinner date. Harry Belafonte, 1957 If you've made it this far into this story and somehow still aren't convinced you need alinen button-upin your life, well, here's all the proof you need. Robin Williams, 1995 Awife pleaserwith a whole whack ofdangly chains(and maybe a trim tuft ofchest hair)? Yes, thank you, more please. The Beach Boys, 1962 You might associateflannel shirtswith lumberjacks in the dead of winter, but as the Beach Boys so smartly demonstrate here, they've also been worn for decades by Californian surfers in need of an extra hit of warmth following an early morning sesh. Steve McQueen, 1973 One more McQueen photo just to keep the moodboards fed and happy. This is a great lesson in not overthinking things. A flattering navy tee, a great pair of cutoff jeans, and a hell of a watch—that's all you really need to dress like an absolute king. Denzel Washington, 2006 That's what the beach is about, isn't it? Even on a blustery fall day you can still have a damn good time out there, as Denzel, his excellent leather trench, and his extremely good boy prove here.

title: These Seven Albums Created Modern Stand-Up Comedy
article_text: Rhino’s new box set of the seven comedy albumsRichard Pryormade between 1974 and 1983—released by several record companies, but now referred to collectively as The Warner Bros. Albums—includes an essay by the historian, critic and PryorbiographerScott Saul entitled “The Age of Pryor.” But when you think about the material on these albums, and consider their impact on the modern landscape of culture as well as comedy, even 20 years after Pryor’s death, it’s fair to wonder if the Age of Pryor ever ended. As an entertainer, Pryor was like Steve Jobs’ iPhone pitch—an all-in-one proposition in which the performer in question not only puts all the most important talents together, but is better at each individual skill than anyone on stage or screen ever had been. He was an observational comedian and an irreverent improviser and a physical comedian and a master of sketch and character and an inherently political social critic and a prophet and a riveting confessional comedian who made his life an open book. He was the son of a pimp and the grandson of a madam from Peoria, rejected by the Illinois school system as well as the army, married seven times, arrested numerous times, addicted to every available drug, violent towards himself and others, and rejected over and over again by Hollywood and America. He was an anthropologist performing an autopsy on Black and white America disguised as stand-up comedy, finding humor in the nuances, in how we relate to one another in the streets and the sheets. He brought an entire community to life on stage, a blend of the pop culture he consumed ravenously in movie houses and the colorful, hilarious, frightening community he grew up in. His material on these albums, masterworks finally given their due ina Janus-levelprestige reissue (That N*gger's Crazy, ...Is It Something I Said?, Bicentennial N*gger, Wanted/Richard Pryor Live in Concert(double-LP),Live On The Sunset Strip, andHere and Now) has captivated several generations of pop culture. Not just his themes, style and delivery, but the actual jokes,quoted incessantly in rapfrom the ‘90s to the present (Kendrick Lamaris a stan), and parroted beat for beat by both white and Black comedians from Jim Carrey to Cedric the Entertainer. Without Pryor you don’t get to Eddie Murphy playing his entire family at a dinner table, or Chris Rock and Dave Chappelle’s both comedic and tragic portrayals of crackheads. Pryor was 33 when he recordedThat N*gger’s Crazyone evening in February 1974 in a San Francisco nightclub, but that performance, and that entire period, was the culmination of nearly a decade of work. He had broken big on bothThe Ed Sullivan Showand with Merv Griffin in 1965with sketch performances. He came from a tradition of stand-ups who leaned on character work and sketch in their acts, like Sid Caesar and Jonathan Winters. But unlike those comedians, Pryor would use this “device” to bring an entire sociological study of his Black Midwestern experience to life with detail-rich dimension. Early in his career in New York, playing Village basket houses, he was a crossover act, popular with largely white crowds, performing a cerebral, conceptual act that a modern viewer would understand as improv play. He hadn’t ever quite fit in the Chitlin Circuit tradition of Black comedians playing to mostly Black audiences, like his friend Red Foxx or Pigmeat Markham or Moms Mabley. Nor did he quite fit with the defiant, Civil Rights-influenced young comics of his peer group, like Dick Gregory and Godfrey Cambridge. Of his contemporaries, he ironically was probably closest in style to Bill Cosby, another comedian who would put on skits— Noah receiving IKEA-style ark-construction directions from God, the indignity of the dentist—though he would later think of himself, and be thought of, as “The Anti-Cosby.” For Pryor, finding his voice and finding his career was a journey. For a time his working life was bifurcated—playing by industry rules afforded to Black entertainers and cultivating an inoffensive screen persona on shows likeThe Partridge Family, while spending his free time on projects like the never-completedUncle Tom’s Fairy Tales,an experimental underground film that imagined the commingling of the concurrent Black and sexual revolutions. He moves around, from New York to LA, from LA to Berkeley, back to LA. He becomes disenchanted with the frustrating low-level fame he achieves and hungers for connection with Black audiences and Black issues in his material. He finds valuable collaborators like Paul Mooney, Lily Tomlin, and Mel Brooks, who are fearless in their transgressive work, as well as a community of serious Black artists, like the writers Cecil Brown, Ishmael Reed and Al Young. He falls in love and falls out of it. He begins incorporating profanity into his act around the time he begins to turn inward (and around the periodobscenity laws are beginning to become more laxwhen it comes to public expression), and notably begins using the N-word in a manner it had never been employed on stage before. In doing so, he’s not pushing boundaries for the sake of pushing them, but to change the way we think and talk about concepts of race, sexuality, and freedom in an honest, frank manner that uses humor to strip away some of their power. But by 1974, and on the subsequent Warner records, you can listen to Pryor inventing the modern format of standup comedy in real time. What he’s finally able to put together in his mature era is his personal history, pain, pathos, struggles with women, sex, drugs, money and fame, all examined from the perspective of a suppressed Black man finally enjoying free expression and finding more acclaim and popularity than he did when he played by society’s rules. It can be understood as a rejection of the limited options, the voice the entertainment industry forced on Pryor, and an embrace of his own taste, his own narrative. Along withMuhammad Ali, Richard was a Black celebrity who you could argue was just before his time—but you could just as easily argue that neither man could have arrived at the “right time.” Both Pryor and Ali were a tide change, necessary to put one conception of Black celebrity in America to rest, so a new one could begin. Pryor found unfathomable success beginning withThat N****** Crazy, an X-rated phenomenon of an album that was impossible to promote but still sold a half million records, and won a Grammy (as did four other albums in the collection). It was a record that expanded the conventional imagination when it came to what a comedy album was capable of accomplishing in terms of popularity and cultural impact. The films Pryor acted in all have moments but are never quite as good as you remember or want them to be. He never really got or wrote a script worthy of his incredible talent (with the exception ofhis role inWattstax), and he was denied the chance to star in what should’ve been his masterpiece—Blazing Saddles, the Black Western comedy he co-wrote with Mel Brooks. His one-season eponymous TV variety series also had moments of greatness, but the idea Pryor could’ve ever found a true platform on 70s network television seems even more insane now than it did then. In lieu of that, we’ll always have over five hours of standup, finally in a packaging befitting their genius and majesty. They are Richard Pryor’s lasting, unqualified masterpieces.

title: 20 Best Mother’s Day Gifts From Gucci, According to GQ
article_text: All products are independently selected by our editors. If you buy something, we may earn an affiliate commission. Moms—the really good ones—spend all year long thinking about you. If you’re emotionally fulfilled and intellectually nurtured. If you’re stretching yourself just enough to squeeze the good stuff out of life. If you’re eating your veggies, texting your dates back, and wearing sunscreen. So forMother’s Day, it’s worth returning the favor—even just for a day, even just through a gesture. If we may, don’t overthink this: Turn toGucci. The Italian brand, beloved for its whimsical threads, makes a gift feel like more than a memory. In place of a fresh bouquet that's bound to wilt in a week, try a floral printed scarf that’ll bloom again each spring. Rather than giving her your go-to body butter set, up your game with lipsticks and fragrances that will have her dreaming of Florence. Here, our guide to the no-fail gifts that will show her you care through a single, simple gesture. The Italian illustrator Vittorio Accornero created the Flora Scarf in 1966 for Grace Kelly, and the lush and expressive floral print became an instant icon. Since then, the brand’s dreamy, untamed florals havegraced the necksof not only princesses but celebrity royalty (ahem: Rihanna) as well. Your mother—yourqueen—will appreciate one of these squares just as much. Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci All the while you were in diapers, your mom lost out on the chance to carry afabulous handbagto accommodate all of your bits and bobs. It’s all been forgiven, of course, but there’s no time like the present to make that feel like a long and distant memory with a Gucci handbag. Four we think are winners for the long haul: The Ophidia Small Boston bag, which has the brand’s classic red and green stripe atop its icon webbed print, the chic black Marmont Mini bag with the GGs on the clasp, the Diana Large Tote bag that (for the right mom) could hold a handful of diapers, and the Gucci Horsebit 1955 bag—which in our humble opinion is the one to beat. Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci When you give a gift from Gucci, you’re handing over a piece from a brand with a long and storied history, not unlike your relationship with your ma. Take the horsebit, a design detail that firstappeared on a loaferover 70 years ago in 1953 (yes, your mom probably wants said loafers if she doesn’t already have ‘em in her closet). Today, the horsebit can be found on details throughout the brand’s line, such as bags, dresses, and—our personal favorite—jewelry. In 18K rings and earrings, the horsebit is recognizable, but it feels fresh and playful, making it a great gift for a mom who doesn’t mind a subtle nod to a brand rather than an outright logo. For moms who would rather cut to the chase, snag one of the brand’s interlocking Gucci Gs in the form of a necklace or studs. Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Shopping for clothingis hard if you start from a place of need. Almost certainly, your mom is always cold (or hot!) and could use a cardigan (or tank!). But Mother’s Day is a time to shop for her dreams and not her day-to-day. So: a frock meant for Italian wine tastings? That’ll do! Adouble-breasted blazerthat makes her feel like the boss you know her to be? But of course! A garden-party-ready poplin that you know will bring out her very best self.Ahhh, you shouldn’t have! Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci Gucci We can't say enough good things about Gucci's collection ofloafers, and these two options were hand-picked by one shoe-obsessedGQeditor for their sleek silhouette, versatility, and classic charm. The brand's incredible attention to detail shines here, folks. Trust us: Mom is going to love them. A swipe of a lipstick or a spritz of scent cue our brain to form memories about who she was and what she wore, and whether you’re looking to tap into nostalgia or give her a new view of herself, Gucci’smakeupmakes a great gift. Originally launched in 2014 in collaboration with makeup icon Pat McGrath, the lipsticks and fragrances have always been the standouts. Give her a tube of Goldie Red, a high pigment, longwearing matte lipstick in a gold, beveled case or the brand’s orchid scent which pushes a vanilla heart note as far from blasé as possible. title: Jonathan Anderson’s Dior Men Debut Is Sooner Than You Think
article_text: During the annual LVMH shareholders call on Thursday, Bernard Arnault confirmed the news that the fashion world has been anticipating for months:Jonathan Andersonis the new artistic director ofDior Men. The LVMH kingpin also disclosed an unexpected scoop: Anderson’s debut is only two months away. The designer is set to unveil his vision for Dior Men atParis Fashion Weekin June. June 27 at 2:30 p.m., to be exact, according to a subsequent press release circulated by Dior. Anderson’s next move has been the talk of the industry since last September, when he took a tearful bow at a Loewe runway show that had the emotional weight (and aesthetic crescendo) of a grand finale. Though designer-swap rumors are a dime a dozen these days, it’s fair to say that Anderson’s career has taken on a genuine importance inside and out of fashion. In his 11 years atLoewe, Anderson—funny, whip-smart, boyish, and a little nerdy—followed his taste in art and knack for imaginative silhouettes to turn a once-obscure Spanish leather label into a “cultural brand” that charmed casual shoppers and wowed elite tastemakers. All while continuing to evolve his language of humorous, conceptual menswear at his London-basedJW Anderson label. By the time the designerdeparted Loewe in March, it was clear that if we were in for amen’s fashion vibe shift, it would be led by Anderson, who has real modern range: he has made audiences look at the men’s suit in a new way, and has also inspired aviral meme about an heirloom tomato. At that point, his destination was an open secret—the talk of Paris Fashion Week was that he was already punching the clock at the Dior studio, where hesucceeds Kim Joneson the men’s side of the atelier. Still, without an official confirmation of his appointment, and amidst further speculation about LVMH’s plans to hand him the keys to Dior womenswear, it was unclear when we would see what he’s evidently been working on. Further questions remain: In his new role, will Anderson still be Luca Guadagnino’sgo-to costume designer? What does it mean for JW Anderson? Will Daniel Craig beholding down the front rowin June? For his part, Anderson wasted no time giving us a sneak peek. Shortly after the news broke, heposteda photo on Instagram of the back of a blue striped men’s shirt. Pinned to it is a label of a retro house logo. Anderson’s caption said it all: “Dior.”

title: Story mfg.’s Plaid-Wrapped Asics Collab Is a Picnic Blanket for Your Feet
article_text: When it comes toselecting collaborators, Asics doesn’t copy any other sneaker brand’s playbook. Despite itsrecent mainstream hits, the Japanese maker has always largely catered to a niche audience and seems to value finding collaborators with the same ethos. Whether that’s eclectic brands likeBentgablenitsor gorpy gods likeHaven, they’ve got a great eye for designers with rich, distinct visions. Story mfg.is the latest and greatest addition to the family. The Brighton-based brand was founded by Saeed and Katy Al-Rubeyi back in 2013, long before “sustainability” became fashion’s ultimate buzzword. They never cut corners in crafting their clothes, prioritizing ethically-sourced textiles, an adherence to making vegan-friendly product, and minimizing the use of harmful chemicals in any of their manufacturing processes. It’s worth noting that none of this matters if a brand isn’t making dope clothes, and Story Mfg. very much does. They bring their artful eye for color and print to drapey, modern silhouettes. Story Mfg.’s clothes are practical and functional, but they’re also joyful and expressive—the furthest thing from boring. The label’s Asics debut, then, is just about everything you’d want from a Story mfg. shoe. The collaboration consists of two colorways of the Asics Gel-Venture 6: The first blends creamy vanilla tones with spring-friendly violet accents, while the second decks the silhouette out in a chocolatey brown. Checkered prints adorn both shoes, as do big, floppy checkered laces. It’s a fashion-forward look, sure—but it’s also extremely fun. We’d call this one a match made in sneaker heaven. The partnership between Asics and Story mfg. is off to a great start, and we’re certainly hoping it’s far from finished. After a limited (and instantly sold-out) drop through Story mfg. last week, the shoes will receive a proper global release on April 18 through Asics and selected retail partners. Each pair goes for $160.

title: I Was Halfway Through ‘The Pitt’ When My Father Died. Here's What It Was Like to Finish It
article_text: Early in season one ofThe Pitt,a middle-aged woman is forced to come to terms with her father’s imminent death from natural causes. When we first meet her, she’s something of a problem patient, repeatedly rebuffing our hero, the twinkle-eyed resident surgeon Dr. Robby, when he tries to explain that any more attempts to keep her father alive will actually just bring him more pain while only temporarily delaying the inevitable. It takes a couple episodes for this to sink in, and after it finally does, during her father’s final moments, she laments the unfairness of it all and wishes they’d had more time. That was the last episode ofThe Pittthat I watched before learning that my own dad had suddenly passed away. I remember the first thing I watched in the aftermath of getting the news: the next episode in my queue for the final season ofYou. I needed to do something in those wrenching in-between hours of inactivity and it needed to be as far away from reality as possible. Joe Goldberg wreaking stalker mania havoc on trust-fund one-percenters fit the bill. But as the days and weeks went by, I felt an almost perverse urge to return toThe Pitt.I’m not sure if it was a play at defiance, to prove that I could and would be able to handle something as innocuous and evergreen as depictions of death and loss in art. Another part of me wondered if watching people grapple with death, in most cases sudden and unexpected, would offer some kind of comfort or catharsis. Crucially, it was an experiment I wanted to undergo alone. Even with a house full of family on hand to support me, I didn’t want to feel like someone was watching me watch something that could reflect my real circumstances at any given moment. Smash-cut to the wee hours of the morning, me in full vamp mode, as the rest of the house slept, pressing play on what must have been episode six or seven ofThe Pittand, to my surprise…feeling nothing. It was as easy, enjoyable, and escapist as it had been a week before, even with all the dying patients, conversations about sudden loss, and early-onset grief. A subplot involving an older, loquacious Black man charming the ER staff alongside his exasperated son reminded me of being in the hospital with my dad during a Covid scare years ago, him trying to deflate any tension or anxiety with non-stop jokes—but in a matter-of-fact way. Nothing that had me rushing to turn off the television. I felt relieved, reassured, emboldened even. Surely something soon would pull the rug out from underneath me—the game is the game—but in the meantime, I wasn’t fragile enough to crumble at any given moment or in the face of the more obvious red flags. Then a funny thing happened. I put on an episode ofFrasier, my go-to sleep-timer TV show, the ideal, unfussy sitcom for people who can’t fall asleep to silence. Frasier and Martin were commiserating about something, in a scene I’ve likely seen dozens of times. But in this particular moment it hit differently. A guy in his 40s, finding new ways to relate to his father. I’m in my mid-30s and suddenly that experience is no longer in the cards for me. That brief moment changed the whole texture and DNA of one of my favorite shows. No intubations, flatlines, or conversations about loss, and yet it choked me up. I’ve kept up the nighttimeFrasierroutine every night since, but that different perspective is always in the back of my mind now. As is the certainty that more moments like this are on the horizon.

title: Can Kat Abughazaleh Help Democrats Grow a Spine?
article_text: Kat Abughazaleh leans over her campaign manager’s shoulder as they review a video from her live appearance on CNN Max the night before. “I want to see if I rolled my eyes,” she says, eyes locked on the screen. “I feel like I did.” It’s late March, less than a week after Abughazaleh, 26, announced her run for Congress in Illinois’s Ninth District—a safe blue seat currently held by longtime incumbent Jan Schakowsky (who is, at 80, more than three times Abughazaleh’s age). Abughazaleh has never held office, but she does have a constituency: around 250,000 followers on both X and TikTok, where she has tracked Fox News misinformation,spoofed conservative “comedians,”and critiqued Republicans and Democrats alike (millions more have come across her viral videos and posts in their feeds). Now, though, she’s testing what it means to translate that internet influence and persona into a real campaign and, ultimately, policy. Onscreen, anchor Jim Sciutto pivots from questions about inflation and Democratic inaction to the subject of transgender health care and whether Democrats have moved too far left. The screen splits between Sciutto and Abughazaleh, seated in front of her signature blue microphone. She doesn’t flinch (but yes, she does roll her eyes). “Absolutely not,” she replies. “The idea that Democrats lost the election because of trans people is ridiculous and offensive.” She goes on to explain that trans and queer communities are often the first targets under “authoritarian and fascist regimes”—and that reinforcing those narratives only strengthens authoritarian power. The real problem, she argues, isn’t messaging but disconnection. It’s that voters don’t feel heard, that the political system is run by politicians who are fundamentally out of touch. It’s the kind of moment that another first-time congressional candidate and her campaign manager might later dissect, anticipating any potential backlash. Abughazaleh rushes to post it on her channels. “No, We Aren’t Losing Over Wokeness: Explaining Why Dems Can’t Move Right With CNN’s Jim Sciutto” she titles her YouTube clip. She makes her eye roll the thumbnail, then shares the link on BlueSky (the X alternative that has attracted the MSNBC set, where she has about 180,000 followers), writing:This is the type of rhetoric you can expect from me as a Congresswoman. I have no interest in debating fake narratives and human rights. Abughazaleh has stepped into the political arena at a moment when the Democratic Party finds itself in an existential spiral. While party leaders debate how—or even whether—to confront rising authoritarianism, Abughazaleh has already picked a side. When she announced her run for Congress on March 24 with a two-minute video, her message was blunt: Democrats need to grow a spine. The launch felt less like a campaign kickoff and more like a rallying cry. And it worked. Within a week, Abughazaleh raised over $300,000, with an average donation hovering around $32. Headlines followed inThe Washington Post,Newsweek,Vanity Fair,The Hill, and others. Her video reached 350,000 views on TikTok and another 130,000 on YouTube. One thousand people also signed up to volunteer for the campaign. Elsewhere, Democratic leaders’ approval ratings have slumped, and a majority of Americans say it’s time to remove the aging political old guard in favor of new, less elderly leadership. Abughazaleh’s campaign raises a set of questions the Democratic Party has yet to answer with any coherence: What does the party’s future actually look like? Could it (should it?) be populist leftist candidates who dismantle the establishment and reject neoliberalism? Or, as Scuitto suggested in his questions (and influential centrist thinkers like Matthew Yglesiasargue), are more-moderate politicians better positioned to win back voters and stop Trump from destroying American democracy? These aren’t abstract concerns. Abughazaleh is a half-Palestinian, Gen Z woman running in the post-Roe,unleashed-Trump era. She’s unapologetically left and already a lightning rod for conservative ire. She also knows the right-wing echo chamber inside and out—the full MAGA cinematic universe—and she’s happy to dive headfirst into the culture wars. Her candidacy could prove to be a blip or a bellwether. But in the yearlong lead-up into the primaries, as Trump presumably continues to run roughshod over our economy, institutions, and the rule of law, and the balm of a blue-wave midterm seem impossibly far off, Abughazaleh will help answer a critical question: Can Democrats summon even a spark of excitement from the depths of their darkness? “The establishment Democratic opinions are calcified,” says Hasan Piker, a progressive media personality whose Twitch streams and YouTube content have made him a key figure in leftist internet discourse (if not the “liberal Joe Rogan”). “And too little too late on the policy side. We need bold actionable changes and people who will fight for those changes. This is what makes Kat a great fighter for the moment.” Younger candidates know what they believe in, says Amanda Litman, cofounder and executive director of Run for Something, an organization that recruits and supports young progressive candidates in down-ballot races. “They're showing you who they are to build trust. That’s what the Democratic Party needs now more than ever—to rebuild trust with voters.” Several of these new challengers have already announced their candidacies. They include Jake Rakov, a 37-year-old opposing 70-year-old Rep. Brad Sherman, and Saikat Chakrabarti, 39, who has mounted a challenge against former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. And there’s Zohran Mamdani, a 33-year-old Democratic Socialist, running for mayor in New York City. Millennial and Gen Z candidates know the digital ecosystem in a way older politicians who aren’t named Trump simply don’t. “Kat has a very pragmatic approach to the internet,” saysGarbage Daywriter Ryan Broderick, who has written extensively about the online right and followed Abughazaleh’s career for several years. “She understands how to play the game.” While many establishment Democrats are still stuck in what Broderick calls “2010s liberal cringe,” Abughazaleh’s tone is much more current. “It’s both earnest and playful, but serious when it needs to be. She’s willing to step into the ring and say, This game is rigged. It’s broken. And they’re lying to you.” After graduating from George Washington University, Abughazaleh started working at Media Matters, a progressive nonprofit focused on monitoring and correcting conservative misinformation in US media. Her job was to watch hours of Fox News, tracing how a lie moved from a Tucker Carlson monologue to a chyron to a congressional talking point. After work, she started turning the camera on herself, posting videos that unpacked what she’d seen. Her clips began circulating and she quickly built a viewership. Abughazaleh’s recent CNN appearance marked an early attempt to apply her online fluency to more traditional media streams. The segment’s real life, however, began once she clipped, re-captioned, and circulated it on social platforms, where political identity is increasingly shaped. Less than a week after Abughazaleh posted the edit, it had already racked up nearly 50,000 views on YouTube and another 33,000 on TikTok. Campaign donations ticked upward too. There’s a dark side to viral fame, of course, especially for a young woman. Abughazaleh has blond hair, round blue eyes, and symmetrical features, and she leans into a femme aesthetic. “I have all the makings of a trad wife, except what comes out of my mouth and what’s going on in my brain,” she says wryly. The contrast seems to short-circuit something in the minds of online trolls and inspire a particularly deranged strain of hate. “It drives them insane. They get so confused and triggered by women they’re attracted to.” To illustrate this for me, she pulls up the hundreds of comments on her campaign-announcement video. Nestled among the racist jokes about her name and epitaphs like “Marxist cunt,” there’s one that reads,“How can someone so hot have such bad opinions?” “You don’t have to say that!” she exclaims. “No one is forcing you to call me hot while you insult me.” That comment reminds her of another one she read recently. “Some guy told me he was jacking off to my video and it de-radicalized him,” she says, deadpan. “Like, I’m glad you’re not a Nazi anymore but also, come on.” Among the many men Abughazaleh has managed to piss off is one of the most powerful in the country. In 2023, Elon Musk sued Media Matters for defamation after the organization published a report showing that major brands’ ads were appearing alongside pro-Nazi content on X. Last summer, Musk’s lawyers deposed Abughazaleh for, according to her, nothing more than “mean tweets.” While she can’t speak about the ongoing lawsuit, Abughazaleh doesn’t hold back when it comes to Musk himself. “He wants to be liked so bad. He bought an entire website [Twitter, now X] to make people like him, and it didn’t work,” she says. “In fact, people hate him so much that he can wave millions of dollars underneath their noses and they still won’t like him. Elon Musk is a loser.” The opportunity to confront men like Musk motivated Abughazaleh to run. Few things toughen a person faster than being an outspoken young woman on the internet. And after years of fending off trolls, Abughazaleh is ready for a bigger fight. “People are begging their representatives to do something,” she says. When members of the DOGE team forced their way into government networks, including the federal payment system, politicians “should have been standing arm-in-arm in front of every single treasury entrance. They shouldn’t have let Elon Musk's goons in there.” The thought that Democrats sat back and let it happen infuriates Abughazaleh. “People want to know that they’re being defended and that someone cares about their rights. They gave you this job, so you should do it.” And if not, Abughazaleh adds, “I will.” In person, Abughazaleh defies the caricature of someone shaped by internet outrage. A few days before the CNN interview, I sit with her in a café on Chicago’s North Side, where she’s hosting her first campaign “office hours.” Under skies hesitating between winter and spring, Abughazaleh radiates a kind of seasonal optimism. She’s dressed in a blue linen romper, a loose-knit fruit-themed sweater, and Cloudnova sneakers in a muted 1970s orange-and-pink colorway. She’s warm and at ease among the half-dozen strangers who’ve come to meet her. The idea that the current system isn’t working unites the small group gathered here. And Abughazaleh intends to run a different kind of campaign, one that invests funds back into the community rather than spend money on consultants and traditional advertising. At her launch event, for example, Abughazaleh asked for period product donations rather than an entrance fee. At this table, Abughazaleh’s strategy is met with enthusiasm—not just because she’s trying to build a ground game from scratch, but because her supporters see her approach as the only way to outmaneuver the Democratic machine. “AOC caught the Democrats sleeping at the wheel,” one supporter says. “They thought, Hispanic girl, bartender, whatever—she’s not going to be a problem. They were wrong. And once it started, they couldn’t stop it. They had to give her a seat at the table. And now, they’ll never let themselves get caught like that again.” On Fox News, anchor Jesse Watters called Abughazaleh a “far-left influencer” hijacking the Democratic Party. But Abughazaleh has also been asked in good faith about why she is challenging Congresswoman Jan Schakowsky, a popular, vocal, and progressive representative for IL-9, who has run almost entirely unopposed in primaries since she took office in 1999. Abughazaleh has said Schakowsky has been good, but she will be better. (As of early April, Schakowsky had not yet announced whether she’d seek reelection.) For the young man at the café, though, Abughazaleh’s appeal is obvious. “Kat’s authentic,” he says. “She’ll take care of her people and she’ll fucking fight.” One key issue that distinguishes Abughazaleh from most American politicians, including other Democrats, is her stance on Gaza. Outspoken in her criticism of the war, she has been labeled “anti-Israel” by opponents—a tag that could prove difficult to shake in her district, where many voters are Jewish. (Schakowsky has also supported resolutions to limit arms transfers to Israel, citing humanitarian concerns.) “It’s pretty basic,” Abughazaleh says. “I believe in basic human rights. War crimes are a bad thing no matter who commits them. No matter who they’re being committed against.” Whether her positions resonate with people outside Abughazaleh’s regular orbit—like the younger Americans who are“more likely to sympathize with the Palestinian people than the Israeli people”—remains harder to measure. And incumbency is very hard to overcome, especially in a race where the incumbent is a respected progressive with deep Chicago roots and the newcomer is especially new—Abughazaleh only moved to Chicago last July. But in many ways, says Run for Something’s Litman, the campaign will send an important message, regardless of the outcome. “If Kat’s campaign inspires even 10 more like her to run,” says Litman, “that in itself is a victory.” “I’m going to tell people exactly what I care about and what I believe in,” says Abughazaleh. “And if they don’t like it—well, that’s democracy, baby.”

title: Everything You Need to Know About the Mets’ Collab With New York or Nowhere
article_text: In just five short years, the lifestyle brand New York or Nowhere has become nearly as ubiquitous in the five boroughs asblock-long lines, bacon egg ‘n cheeses, and people awkwardly carrying enormous plants they bought on Facebook Marketplace home on the subway. The popular label has already partnered with New York institutions likeSaturday Night Liveand the New York City marathon on previous collections—as well as theKnicks,Yankees, and Rangers—and now it’s time for the Mets to get in on the fun. Photo courtesy of New York or Nowhere The Mets collection—which drops today, following ateaser campaign starring franchise legend Mike Piazza—includes varsity jackets, T-shirts, hoodies, crew necks, and baseball hats. There’s children’s apparel, too, so the whole family can be decked out in NYON when they trek to Citi Field. For a label as predicated onNYC cultureas New York or Nowhere, continuing to work with the city’s beloved sports teams is a home run (and, in this case, keeps impassioned Mets fans from screaming at them about being left out). A few days before the threads went on sale, GQ caught up with NYON creative director Quincy Moore, as well as James Benesh, the Mets’ VP of Ballpark Experience, to get the inside scoop on how these two inescapable Big Apple cultural forces merged. Quincy Moore:One of my earliest memories is going to Mets games at Shea [Stadium] in the ’90s with my dad. Bobby Bonilla was my favorite player at the time, and we’d always sit behind the third base dugout so we could cheer him on. I’ll never forget how the stadium would literally shake after the Mets made a big play. Airplanes constantly flying overhead. Concrete and rusty seats. That place was rough around the edges and I loved it! The Mets have always had soul, but now it feels likethere’s an aura surrounding the team, especially after last season’s magical run and the [Juan] Soto signing. They deserve all of our attention. They’re one of the best organizations—with the most loyal and passionate fans—in professional sports. James Benesh:Over the past few years, our vision for team merchandise has evolved beyond the standard ballpark apparel. We’ve made a concentrated effort to focus on strategic collabs with culturally relevant, fashion-forward lifestyle brands. That’s allowed us to expand and offer a much wider array of female offerings and streetwear pieces. This started withAimé Leon Doreand Siegelman Stable, and now partnering with New York or Nowhere is a huge next step. Our fans have been clamoring for a collaboration with New York or Nowhere for quite some time, and we’re happy we can deliver with such an extensive collection from the iconic brand. It’s a partnership that just makes sense for both parties. We can’t wait to see these pieces in our ballpark and on thestreets of New York City! Photo courtesy of New York or Nowhere Moore:The varsity jacket is the most iconic piece ofAmerican sportswearthat exists. It’s timeless, endlessly stylish, and lends itself incredibly well to various interpretations and fabrications. This collection includes three variations of the same silhouette—one with a wool body and leather sleeves, one in 100% cotton twill for more of aworkwearvibe, and the last in this beautiful Japanese satin that feels equal parts nostalgic and now. We finished them off with multiple forms of embroidery, including chenille and appliqué, as well as a trio of sleeve patches. As a designer, the varsity jacket is easily my favorite canvas. It sets the perfect foundation for a collection like this, which is ultimately rooted in heritage and fandom. Moore:The feedback has been overwhelmingly positive. This project has been in motion for over two years, and the Mets have been incredible partners throughout. They’ve trusted our vision from the jump, which I think has resulted in some of our strongest work as a brand to date. Players have shown a lot of love, too. We create these collections for the fans, first and foremost, but it’s always icing on the cake when the squad embraces the product as well. Pete Alonso has worn NYON in the past, so we made sure he was the first guy to receive pieces from the collection. [Francisco] Lindor requested a bunch of stuff. The GOAT—that’s the greatest owner of all time—Alex Cohen wore one of the varsity jackets to the first home game. The response has been pretty humbling, both internally and externally. Benesh:We’re thrilled with what we’ve seen. Not only does the look and feel of the collection marry our brand’s history and imprint with New York or Nowhere’s fashion-forward take. But beyond that, we’re happy that we can offer our fans such an extensive collection. Fromhoodies, hats and shirts, to streetwear apparel like jackets and accessories, there’s a New York or Nowhere piece for all of our fans, adults and kids alike. Moore:Each collection always informs the next. Our work with New York sports teams started with the Knicks back in 2018, which eventually led to projects with the Yankees, Rangers, andnow the Mets. Having the opportunity to iterate has allowed us to refine our design process and gain a deeper understanding of what makes this type of product resonate with the fans. There’s a secret sauce, for sure, but the recipe continues to evolve. Moore:All I’ll say is that theYankeesmade the World Series after we dropped our collab with them last season. Hopefully we’ll bring the Mets similar luck!

title: The Best Christopher Nolan Movies
article_text: Christopher Nolan is the biggest brand-name movie director since the days ofSteven SpielbergorGeorge Lucas, which puts him in the running for biggest brand-name movie director of all time, at least in the realm of English-language cinema. (Although: His movies are overseas sensations, too.Tenetdidn’t make $350 million worldwide off of a blockbuster U.S. release.) The strange thing about this is that Spielberg at his commercial peak was considered a populist, a director whose name became synonymous with big, mass-appeal hits and his ability to make them. Especially post-Batman, Nolan seems uniquely well-positioned to engineer those hitsfromhis name, maintaining a perception that he’s an artsy auteur even as he makes billion-dollar smashes. He’s a fusion, then, of Spielberg-level monocultural ubiquity and dorm-room-poster quasi-alternative cool—which is to say, for hardcore film people, he’s probably come to seem more than a little square, a basic-bro cliché refreshed for the geek generation. (The James Cameron of Stanley Kubricks?) That’s more about perception of his movies than their vivid alternate realities, however. Despite his nerdy British rep, the increasing size and scale of Nolan’s work is best expressed by the smooth insinuation of Eames,Tom Hardy’s character inInception: “You mustn’t be afraid to dream a little bigger, darling.” His work calls back to noir and war pictures while looking ahead with sci-fi headiness; the further into his career he gets, the more distinctive and inimitable his style becomes, interestingly dependent on editing, score, and tempo as much as a purely visual signature. It’s a fascinating evolution for a filmmaker whose work so often hinges on men who struggle for some greater, perhaps impossible control over their environment. The best Christopher Nolan movies make big-budget blockbusters feel like canvas for art, rather than endless monetization machinery. There’s not a bad film in the bunch, so let’s rank them all. Isn’t it kind of nice to have a designated last-place dweller on this list that likely won’t bother anybody? Surely there are someFollowingpartisans, and there’s plenty to like about Christopher Nolan’s debut; before you even get to the hooky budget-noir premise – an aspiring novelist starts following people at random and meets a criminal, becoming ensnared in his world of deception in the process – there’s the fact that it’s a 70-minute movie shot on black-and-white 16mm film, essentially a scrappy student film with the chops to score a limited indie release. But this is also a filmmaker who has excelled in the studio space, with the top-notch actors, practical effects, and bigger canvases those jobs have afforded him, so this one can’t help but look a bit slim by comparison. (In a clear case of “take what you can get,” this is the only Nolan movie in the Criterion Collection.) That said, it would be a kick to see Nolan pick up any of those limitations again, presumably still at a cost greater than the six grand or so this one supposedly cost; imagine the Nolan of 2025 turning in a movie under 90 minutes! Imagine the grain if he blew up a 16mm print to those IMAX screens!Followingis still very much worth seeing, and there’s no shame in its placement here. Who among us wouldn’t hope to place work we did in our twenties below what we worked up to afterwards? Almost all of Nolan’s movies bend time, whether through non-chronological editing, actual time-travel devices, or the occasional “Wait,howmuch time just passed?” elision. Though it creates zero temporal pincer movements,Dunkirkis one of his headiest time-trips, following a World War II troop evacuation from three cross-cut perspectives: characters in land, sea, and air. The unusual trick is that these three stories, though afforded similar amounts of screen time, cover different spans of action. The land evacuation takes place over one week, the sea material takes place over one day, and the air mission happens in a single hour. It’s likeInception’s dream-layered climax recreated in real life. On a purely practical level, the movie can be a little hard to follow, because it features a bunch of pasty, largely uniformed English guys running, sailing, and flying around in great numbers, depending on action far more than dialogue or characterization. Even more so than many of Nolan’s visually spectacular films,Dunkirkis best seen in a format that’s vanishingly difficult to actually attain: full 70mm film IMAX, which is available at all of about 20 U.S. locations. That’s why, terrifically visceral as it is, the movie doesn’t rate higher here; its full immersive effect (still occasionally imitated in films as diverse in style as1917andWarfare) can't be reproduced in your living room, no matter how big your TV is. On the other hand, Nolan’s most comfortably rentable at-home movie might be this remake of a 1997 Norwegian film that most buffs agree is the superior take on the material. But there’s something deeply appealing about a Nolan movie that now feels like an entry from an alternate universe where he became the best Warner Bros. auteur of TNT-ready programmers. Al Pacino plays a guilt-ridden cop sent to a night-free town in Alaska to investigate a serial killer—played by Robin Williams, in the more overtly evil but also less showy of his two against-type bad-guy roles of 2002. (The other is the more histrionic if still chillingOne Hour Photo.) Pacino v. Williams makes for a surprisingly effective and satisfying mid-movie face-off; it may not beHeat-level, but this is a rock-solid noir with capable support from Hilary Swank, Nicky Katt, and Maura Tierney. LikeFollowing,Insomniaalmost makes you wish there were a couple more of these in Nolan’s filmography before he gets to the big leagues (not that directing one of the best Pacino movies of the 2000s is exactly small potatoes). Boy, it would be perfect if the story ofTenet, obviously conceived well before its 2020 release date, had a stronger allegorical connection to COVID, because it feels like the movie’s reputation was very much forged and then re-forged in that particular crucible. Nolan notoriously agitated for Warner Bros. to make this erstwhile summer event movie the world’s big return-to-cinema marker in September 2020, before anyone had vaccines, to muted and uncomfortable overall reaction, exacerbated by the obtuse nature of the movie’s sci-fi plotting. (The not-even-subtext of the reactions included a bit of: All of that, forthis?) Then, when it did hit streaming, it was gradually embraced as the kind of opulent Pure Cinema studios have largely refused to make in recent years, especially as many people tried to forget about the pandemic, whether to escape for a couple of hours to put the trauma out of mind. To that end, maybe there’s something to be said for the movie’s villain (Kenneth Branagh) essentially deciding that the world might as well end for everyone else if it’s going to end for him; there’s a glimmer of both pandemic-era selfishness and doominess to that monstrous yet weirdly relatable instinct. Or maybe the movie works as a testament to the much-needed power of human connection, because while the time-in-reverse mechanics are often baffling in the moment, the movie works in large part because of the bittersweet camaraderie forged in the midst of all this, between the unnamed Protagonist (John David Washington) and his guide through the twilight world (Robert Pattinson, appropriately). Regardless: Despite its hinkiness feeling like it belongs in some as-yet-unreached Nolan Late Period,Tenetrocks, and may IMAX rep screenings play it back forever. At the time of its release,Batman Beginswas the second-bestBatmanmovie in a walk, so it’s wild that it lands as far down as number eight in Nolan’s canon, behind two additional Batman movies, among others. It’s easy to underrateBeginsbecause it’s a bit more modest, a bit more of a pulpy origin story, than the more ornately ambitious sequels (one of which is quite underrated in its own way). It’s also easy to overrate it for being the first blush of Nolan’s crime-saga take on the Caped Crusader; the relief this represented after the overblown, smirky garishness ofBatman & Robinis difficult to convey to those who weren’t waiting with bated breath for a Bat-movie corrective for eight years following that Clooney-led debacle. (By contrast, it only took Warners four years to re-introduce a live-action Batman after Nolan’s mega-successful Dark Knight trilogy ended.) In the end, it’s also easy to rateBatman Beginsexactly right: As a perfect introduction ofChristian Baleinto the Bruce Wayne/Batman role and one of the most rigorously satisfying superhero origin stories ever made. The movie that should have banished a lot of empty comparisons between Stanley Kubrick and Christopher Nolan instead locked us in for another decade of them, simply because Nolan used a lot of practical effects to shoot a relatively grounded-looking (if still probably scientifically wack) movie set partially on spaceships.Interstellaris a vastly more sentimental movie than anything Kubrick ever made, especially2001, and what it lacks as a visionary trip, it tries to make up in Nolan’s most blatant tearjerking, as in the scene where Cooper (Matthew McConaughey) returns from a time-dilated mission on a far-off planet, seeking a new settlement for the people on Earth, and watches a series of video messages where his children age decades and give him up for dead. It’s especially moving coming from a filmmaker so fixated on the flexibilities of time—an acknowledgment of how some things are immutable, whether it's time’s passage or (as Anne Hathaway’s character argues) the enduring nature of love. It’scornyand beautiful! And while Nolan has been accused of humorlessness, this movie also has a sassy talking robot; truly, something for everyone. I know the movie that won Christopher Nolan some much-deserved Best Picture and Best Director Oscars should probably rate higher; the degree of difficulty involved in making nearly a billion dollars off of a three-hour historical drama about the creation of the atom bomb (and, more impressively, the personal fallout of that creation) is insanely high, andOppenheimeris a hell of an achievement: in getting a bunch of IMAX theaters to play a movie with a bunch of black-and-white scenes; in exposinga bunch of dadsto elliptical and non-linear editing with a stunning lack of exposition; in Nolan ensemble-marshaling in general and briefly remindingRobert Downey Jr.that he’s a real actor in particular; in becoming one of the first movies to kinda feel like a doomscroll but, somehow, not really in a bad way? It’s also a neat companion piece to something likeFirst Man, as it chronicles those crucial first steps toward a possible end of the Earth. (See what I mean about the doomscroll?) The only thing that places this excellent movie out of the top five is the nagging sense that sometimes Nolan’s most serious-minded projects also tend to be his most workmanlike. He’s a sci-fi guy at heart—which is also what gives the movie’s build toward the bomb a hurtling, chilling grandeur. Nolan may have been launched to the next level by big-budget franchise filmmaking, but he knows his way around an ending, and even his middle-of-the-trilogy movie finds a perfect non-cliffhanging stopping point—to such an extent that Nolan actively wondered if he could or should follow upThe Dark Knightat all. He eventually did, with perhaps his most undervalued movie, one that patiently awaits the reclamation so many of his “disappointing” blockbusters enjoy a few years later; the sheer size and scope of this thing is a wonder to behold, especially in a subgenre that so often rushes to world-in-the-balance stakes in stories that nonetheless look and feel pixelated and rinky-dink.The Dark Knight Rises, following Bruce Wayne’s return to the Batman cowl for one last ride eight years after the events ofThe Dark Knight, is an intensely physical movie, befitting a trilogy-capper where Wayne has to strap on a semi-magical leg brace just to continue his Batman antics. He’s joined by an idealistic orphan cop (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) and some kind of Cat Woman (Anne Hathaway); is there a more swoonworthy moment in the Nolan canon than Bruce and Selina fighting henchmen together on the Gotham rooftops? (Probably, but not for me!) Basically, everything inThe Dark Knight Risesthat has incited mass eyerolls – Tom Hardy’s voice-mask combo as bad guy Bane (heavily reconfigured from the comics); the fact that Batman escapes a pit of eternal despair in an undisclosed location and rolls back into Gotham with absolutely no intervening scenes explaining how he got back there; “Robin” – is actually pretty awesome, especially in service of a rare degree of actual superhero-story closure. I know this probably “shouldn’t” be ahead ofOppenheimer, but which one would I be up for rewatching, like, right now? “OK, so what am I doing? Oh, I’m chasing this guy. No, he’s chasing me.” It’s probably the biggest laugh in the Nolan filmography, and it doubles as a high-concept synopsis ofMemento,the reverse-chronological story of Leonard (Guy Pearce), a guy with a hell of a short-term memory problem trying, with a doggedness that seems admirable at first, to solve the mystery of his wife’s death. Informational tattoos, helpful-hint Polaroids, Carrie-Anne Moss as a possible femme fatale, Pearce looking befuddled, Joe Pantoliano going “Lenny!”… the imagery, touchstones, and performances ofMementomay be smaller-scale than much of what followed in Nolan’s career, but they’re just as indelible, a necessary reminder that the best Christopher Nolan movies need not cost $200 million to stun us. If anything, his breakout indie hit looks even smarter in (a ha!) retrospect, especially in terms of what it didn’t portend about his future movies. Specifically, it was probably wise of Nolan to mostly abandon the big-twist mechanism that finishes this particular movie with such elan, lest he becomeM. Night Shyamalan(which would ultimately be fine from an artistic point of view, but it's got to be annoying to constantly hear your endings described as “twists”). Instead, the movie’s finale lingers less for the audacity of its rug-pull than its chilling rumination on memories and how we mold them to our use. Two magicians tussle dishonorably for authentic wonder in this Nolan Brothers adaptation of the Christopher Priest novel (Jonathan Nolan makes his first credited return to Christopher’s films since co-writingMemento). I know I just got through praising Nolan for not over-relying on twists, andThe Prestigehappens to have a doozy of one up its sleeve. But this film—perhaps the definitive feature-length attending of that Arthur C. Clarke quote about sufficiently advanced technology being indistinguishable from magic—is precisely about methods of sleight-of-hand, whether old-fashioned commitment or futuristic breakthroughs. It also features one ofHugh Jackman’s very best performances, playing a guy who will do anything to become the greatest showman—a far more interesting precursor, then, to his edgeless, cuddly P.T. Barnum from the hit musical a decade later. We expect to see Christian Bale characters behaving obsessively (and his character here feels like a darkly funny comment on nutty actorly discipline), but there’s something particularly eerie about finding the darkness in Jackman’s top-hatted soul. On top of all that, there’s terrific cinematography, production design, Rebecca Hall and Scarlett Johansson, andDavid Bowieplaying Nikola Tesla. Plenty of other filmmakers would go to outlandish lengths to make a movie this good. It’s a classic for a reason, mergingEmpire Strikes Backshit-gets-real portent withReturn of the Jedi-style cross-cut momentum. Not to always tell it to you inStar Wars, butThe Dark Knightalso finds further kinship with the future entryThe Last Jedi; both movies obviously connect to and deepen their predecessors while working remarkably well as stand-alone stories. (Hence Nolan’s aforementioned reluctance to even make a third Batman movie, though I’m glad he ultimately didn’t pass, orRise of Skywalkerit.) We’ve all read endless run-downs of how greatThe Dark Knightis, and we’ve all seen multiple Joker performances that still live entirely in the shadow of the workHeath Ledgerdoes here, while never managing to be as funny, scary, or original. It’s not just Joker, though. What’s especially funny and strange is that this movie helped kick off an age of Batman saturation we’re still living in; the eight-year gap between Joel Schumacher'sBatman & Robinand Nolan'sBatman Beginsnow seems unthinkable, and in fact it’s far more likely that there will be multiple ongoing movie Batmen at once than none at all. Yet no matter what you think of the individual variations, it’s hard to shake the feeling that this one will be impossible to top. In his own thrilling and slightly self-serious way, did Nolan help gradually kill off the illusion of a healthy long-term superhero cinema?! The obligatory complicated movie that’s at least partially about the complications of moviemaking,Inceptionhas ample opportunities to disappear up its own ass. (If ever there was perfect timing to produce a boondoggle, it would be following the billion-dollar success ofThe Dark Knight.) Yet this dream-heist sci-fi action-drama, where thieves plug into deeper and deeper levels of subconscious to implant and/or steal valuable ideas, somehow maintains a light touch amidst all of the usual straight-faced menace. Yes, the Nolan narrative and stylistic tropes are all here: the obsessive protagonist; the dead wife; the attempt to impose control; the pacing and cutting that sometimes feels like an endless rising montage. Don’t they have to be, working in concert, to play out so well? The stock criticisms ofInceptionare, unsurprisingly, actually describing secret strengths: The torrents of exposition offered to Ariadne (Elliot Page) don't just give the audience the opportunity to catch up on the movie’s heady rules; they’re actively fun and playful, as crucial to drawing us into the mission as scenes where the leader lays out the blueprint for an impending heist. The lack of blatant surrealism in the dreamscapes, meanwhile, reflects the control that mastermind Dom (Leonardo DiCaprio) must attempt to exert in order to manipulate his subjects (and, not unimportantly, is also true to a lot of actual dreams)—and, of course, the recognizable reality that so many big-screen dreams try to stay rooted in, at least on some level. “Always imagine new places,” Dom cautions Ariadne, not to let imagination run wild but for the safety of distinguishing dream from reality. That tension between drilling further into familiar-but-different imaginary spaces—living in that slow-motion shot of the vehicle hurtling off the bridge— and coming back up for real-world air makes the movie more than its rollercoaster of indulgences. It’s a certain kind of magic-trick experience that you can’t stop watching, in hopes of spotting that little wobble of reality. Put in a less convoluted way: Movies likeInceptionare why I love movies.

title: Scientists Discover Hints of Life On Distant Planet
article_text: A Cambridge team of researchers are contending the strongest indication so far of extraterrestrial life. Led by professor Nikku Madhusudhan, the group of researchers studying the atmosphere of a planet called K2-18b has detected signs of molecules that, on Earth, are produced only by living organisms like marine algae. Naturally, the astronomers behind the study,publishedWednesday in the Astrophysical Journal Letters are not jumping to any conclusive statements on the matter, but that isn’t dampening excitement at the preliminary discovery. “This is a revolutionary moment,” Dr. Madhusudhan said during a conference on Tuesday, while also emphasizing that no one is claiming to have found life. “It’s the first time humanity has seen potential biosignatures on a habitable planet.” Hopes for continuing this level of research and exploration face an uphill battle as PresidentDonald Trumphas moved toslash NASA’s science budgetby nearly half under an early version of the administration’s proposed budget to Congress; terminating billions of dollars and effectively pulling the rug out from under current and potential research like Habitable Worlds Observatory, an upcoming NASA mission which could build on Dr. Madhusudhan and his team’s findings. In a statement, NASA pointed to astudyof Hycean exoplanets—which researchers proposed K2-18b could be classified as—as a new frontier for scientists, but one that “requires tens to hundreds of hours of observing time for a single planet.” “To deduce the presence of life from an atmosphere alone, we would also need to know about the planet’s surface, interior, and environment,” the statement continued. “For biosignatures, context is key.” Without funding though, it's unclear whether American scientists could continue their search for context—or life. title: Ex-NPR Chief Says Public Media Could Have Better Prepared for a Trump Gutting
article_text: Vivian Schilleris familiar with Republican calls to defund public media. When Schiller, the former president and CEO of NPR,resignedin 2011, following the controversialfiringofJuan Williamsandvideosurfacing of a fundraising executive criticizing Tea Party lawmakers, the funding debate in Washington, which had beensimmering for decades, gotreignited. While such calls kicked upagainduringDonald Trump’s first presidency, three months into his second term, the risk of losing federal funding, says Schiller, is “greater than it’s ever been in the history of public broadcasting.” News came earlier this week that the Trump White House intends to ask Congressto rescind$1.1 billion in federal funding for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. If the package is passed, it would have major ramifications for NPR and PBS, which rely on the taxpayer-funded corporation to maintain a broad collective of local member stations that serve communities across the country. The White House proposal comes on the heels of a fiery DOGE subcommitteehearingin which NPR president and CEOKatherine Maherand PBS president and CEOPaula Kergerdefended their respective organizations and the federal funding they receive. Trump ally and Georgia representativeMarjorie Taylor Greene,who served as chairperson for the hearing, accused both outlets of airing “propaganda” that is “brainwashing the American people,” and called for “the complete and total defund and dismantling of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.” Similar rhetoric came this week from the White House,which characterizedthe government as being “ripped off” by public media, and accused NPR and PBS of spreading “radical, woke propaganda disguised as ‘news.’” In particular, the White House listed examples of coverage aroundgender,sexuality, andracethat it considered “trash.” In a Wednesday Fox News appearance, Office of Management and Budget directorRussell Voughtconfirmedthe rescission package proposal, including the CPB cuts, and accused NPR and PBS of liberal bias. “They are almost pioneering the cultural indoctrination of our kids, putting drag queens in children’s programs, doing documentaries on pushing for reparations, and dividing a country on the basis of race,” Vought said, adding that the administration is “excited about” the proposal to gut the funding pipeline. Kerger said in a Tuesday statement that “rescinding these funds would devastate PBS member stations and the essential role they play in communities, particularly smaller and rural stations who rely on federal funding for a larger portion of their budgets” and “without PBS member stations, Americans will lose unique local programming and emergency services in times of crisis.” Public television stations serve nearly 97% of the nation, regardless of zip code or income level, and PBS is viewed in 87% of non-internet homes, 56% of low-income homes, and 55% of rural homes, according to data from the company. Maher has also been making a public case for funding, echoing Kerger’s sentiments in aninterviewon Wednesday onAll Things Considered.“If federal funding goes away, that network is absolutely at risk, the quality of service, the ability to cover everyone, people who live in what would otherwise be news deserts,” she said. Maher framed NPR coverage on the local level as “tremendously important as a public service,” given that “about 20% of Americans live in an area without any other local news coverage other than their local public radio station.” The Corporation for Public Broadcasting currently allocates$535 millionannually to public media, a cost of around $1.60 per American taxpayer. The funds, however, are mainly allocated directly to NPR and PBS local member stations, both to maintain newsgathering resources and to license programming from their respective national organization. NPR receives about 1% of its annualoperating budgetdirectly from the federal government, with member stations receiving between 8 and 10%. Some of this then travels upstream to NPR when stations license content, which accounts for 30% of NPR’s revenue. As for PBS, the amount of funding varies slightly from year to year, but it currently sits at around 15% of their revenue, according to the organization. Earlier this month,TheNew York Timesreported the existence of a 36-pagedocumentput together by NPR executives in 2011 that explored what would happen to the organization if federal funding were to be revoked. The document acknowledged that most member stations barely operate at break-even and the slashing of federal funds would “cause up to $240 million to vanish and up to 18 percent of roughly 1,000 member stations to close.” Schiller, who also held high-ranking roles NBC, CNN, Twitter, andTheNew York Times,and is currently the executive director of Aspen Digital, dismissed the claims of liberal bias hurled at public media, telling me, “what this is really about is, frankly, an assault on the free press,” pointing to other recent White House efforts to attack the media, includingbarringthe Associated Press from the briefing room and Trumpsuingbroadcast networks over coverage disputes. Regardless, she says, “Independent journalism and federal funding, it’s a toxic mix.” Schiller adds that while she is shocked that it has taken this long for the funding disputes over public media to finally “blow up,” she believes that “the whole system will be better off” by severing all monetary ties. “I hope that this federal funding does not get rescinded this year,” she says, “but let this be a warning that the time now is to begin to move towards removing that reliance.” “I just wish now that they had taken the last 15 years to start moving along that model, as opposed to now having a gun to the head,” Schiller says. title: Before the Met Gala 2025, Revisit 10 Years of Met Gala Fashion and Themes
article_text: It’s hard to believe it’s been a decade sinceRihannafirst made fashion history at the Met Gala.While she had previously attended the ultra-exclusive event, it was theyellow, fur-trimmed embroidered gownwith a lengthy train by designerGuo Pei, that she wore for “China: Through the Looking Glass” in 2015 that instantly secured her spot on best dressed-lists the world over. “I can’t really walk in it without any help—but it’s so worth it. I love this dress so much! It’s Chinese couture and it’s made by Guo Pei. It’s handmade by one Chinese woman and it took her two years to make. I found it online,”she toldVanity Fairat the time. “I was researching Chinese couture on the Internet and I found it.” A testament to just how inspiring the Met Gala’s theme can be. As the countdown toMet Gala 2025is underway, take a look back at ten years of extravagance, grandeur and history-making fashion. In 2015, the Met Gala celebrated China’s influence on Western fashion. The highlight of the evening?Rihanna’s huge yellow fur dress, created by Chinese designerGuo Pei. Rihanna Jennifer Lopez Lady Gaga In 2016, celebrities drew inspiration from technology for their outfits. WhileKaty Perryimagined her dress with a gothic, futuristic accent,Emma Watsonintrepreted the theme by wearing a dress made of water bottles. That year’s exhibit focused on the difference between handmade and machine-made garments. Emily Ratajkowski Emma Watson Katy Perry Japanese fashion designerRei Kawakubowas the guest of honor at the Met Gala in 2017. Renowned for her innovative creations and offbeat fashion, she dressed many stars that evening, while others were content to draw inspiration from her signature aesthetic. Katy Perry andPharrell Williamswere co-chairs of the event for this edition. Blake Lively Zendaya Hailey Bieber In 2018, the exhibition featured rare artifacts from the Vatican, and so, the evening’s guests were tasked with walking the red carpet dressed in celestial and religious dress codes. Ariana Grande Gigi Hadid Bella Hadid In 2019, the theme was extravagance. Guests showed up in their most eccentric finery. WhileLady Gagatook the theme literally, slipping into a huge, imposing fuchsia-pink ensemble, others played it simple.KendallandKylie Jenner, looked fierce in feathers, one in purple and the other in orange. Kylie et Kendall Jenner Penelope Cruz Lily Rose Depp For the Met Gala’s return after the COVID-19 pandemic, celebrities were instructed to celebrate “American independence.”Billie Eilishtransformed herself in a golden-age Hollywood ball gown, andZoë Kravitzcaused a sensation by daring to wear sheer. Zoë Kravitz Virgil Abloh Kaia Gerber Opulence was at the heart of the Met Gala 2022. That evening, the event also celebrated the role of fashion in American history. Celebrities took the opportunity to honor the country’s most emblematic American designers. Winnie Harlow Cara Delevingne Gigi Hadid Fashion genius and leader of an iconic era in the fashion industry, Karl Lagerfeld was honored at the Met Gala 2023.
